required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Efficiency of HHHFNC Between Unheated Oxygen Therapy in Difficult Weaning Patients After Extubation in RCC
clinical_study.official_title: The Efficiency of Heated Humidifier High-Flow Nasal Cannula Between Unheated Oxygen Therapy in Difficult Weaning Patients After Extubation in Respiratory Care Center

lead_sponsor.agency: Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital

clinical_study.source: Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the efficacy of Heated Humidified High-Flow Nasal Cannula compared with noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation in the prevention of extubation failure in patients with prolonged mechanical ventilation.

detailed_description.textblock:
There have been many clinical trials comparing the role of Heated Humidified High-Flow Nasal Cannula or Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation in the prevention of extubation failure.
These review all have similar results summarized here:
Compared with Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation, Heated Humidified High-Flow Nasal Cannula provides better patient comfort, fewer oxygen desaturation episodes, lower likelihood of interface displacement, and, lower reintubation rate than Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation.
However, most of these clinical trials focused on participants experiencing acute respiratory failure.
Investigators of this study want to find something difference between oh these two groups.

primary_outcome.description: Any placement of an endotracheal tube for any indication within 72 hours of extubation, censored at the first of hospital discharge or 72 hours after extubation.

secondary_outcome.description: Mortality rate, or death rate is a measure of the number of deaths

arm_group.description: Noninvasive Ventilation group initial setting： Insp. Pressure：12 ~ 16 centimeter of water Exp. Pressure ： 4 ~ 6 centimeter of water FiO2：Keep oxygen saturation measured by pulse oximeter：> 92% By condition, gradually tap 2~3 centimeter of water inspiratory positive airway pressure Keep Tidal volume：6~10 ml/kg

arm_group.arm_group_label: Heated Humidified High-Flow Nasal Cannula group
arm_group.description: Heated Humidified High-Flow Nasal Cannula group initial setting： Flow setting: 50 L/m FiO2：Keep oxygen saturation measured by pulse oximeter > 92% temperature:37 ℃ By condition, gradually tap Flow 5 L/m

intervention.description: Participants using of invasive ventilator more than 14 days, maybe considered transferred to the Respiratory Care Center(RCC), participants enrolled to this study and also written informed consent from participants or their family; After extubation, the difficult weaning patients were allocated to two treatment groups, and randomly assigned to Heated Humidified High-Flow Nasal Cannula or Noninvasive Ventilation devices.
intervention.arm_group_label: Heated Humidified High-Flow Nasal Cannula group

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age: Over 20 years of age
- the requirement of at least six hours of mechanical ventilation per day for at least 14 consecutive days
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy
- Status post tracheostomy
- Neuromuscular diseases
- Signed "do not resuscitate" order
- Unplanned extubation

overall_official.affiliation: Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital
